item.title: C# People
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“Evil_, post:16, topic:386062”][quote author=eczema3 link=topic=481814.msg3530381#msg3530381 date=1300126733]
Is it possible to do the same kinda thing for a button? Like:

this.button1.Click += () => { MessageBox.Show("Button clicked"); };
[/quote]

this.button1.Click += (object sender, EventArgs args) =>
{
// Do stuff
};[/quote]
TY, I was wondering if anyone had actually noticed I’d asked that question.

Read full topic

item.title: C# People
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

defining a closure as a first-class function with its free-variables bound to the outer scope (copy-in), they are indeed not closures. this isn’t a problem in immutability-based functional languages.

Read full topic

item.title: C# People
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“super_, post:12, topic:386062”]ANONYMOUS DELEGATES ARE NOT AND DO NOT USE CLOSURES[/quote]ummmmmmmmmmmmm yes they do…

explain to me how the following code works otherwise (not written by me):

using System;

namespace AnonymousMethod

{

    delegate void Func();

    class Test

    {

        static Func[] funcArr = new Func[10];

        static void fillFunc(int count)

        {

            for (int i = 0; i < count; i++)

            {

                funcArr[i] = delegate()

                             {

                                Console.Write("{0} ", i);

                             };

            }

        }

        static void Main(string[] args)

        {

            fillFunc(funcArr.Length);

            for (int i = 0; i < funcArr.Length; i++)

            {

                funcArr[i]();

            }

        }

    }

}

Read full topic

item.title: C# People
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“super_, post:8, topic:386062”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=481814.msg3530734#msg3530734 date=1300143416]

en.wikipedia.org

Closure (computer programming)

In programming languages, a closure (also lexical closure or function closure) is a technique for implementing lexically scoped name binding in a language with first-class functions. Operationally, a closure is a record storing a function[a] together with an environment. The environment is a mapping associating each free variable of the function (variables that are used locally, but defined in an enclosing scope) with the value or reference to which the name was bound when the closure was crea Ex...

java 7 will support this
[/quote]

anonymous closures* are not delegates moron[/quote]…i never said that either moron

and eczema, it relates to the fact that delegates use closures

Read full topic

item.title: C# People
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

It’s just a delegate.

It works for Thread’s constructor because it accepts a ThreadStart delegate as a parameter.

Read full topic

item.title: C# People
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

The fuck is this:

Constructor(() => { //do stuff here });

I’ve only ever seen it used when initialising a Thread:

new Thread(() => { //Thread stuff here }).Start();

So I’m not sure if it’s Threads only or what, but regardless, the fuck?

Read full topic
